summary: This document is the official protocol for the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program (EVCP), established to compensate victims of sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein. It outlines the program's voluntary, independent administration by Kenneth R. Feinberg and Camille S. Biros, eligibility criteria, claims process, evaluation factors, and confidentiality provisions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure whose estate established the compensation program for victims of his alleged sexual abuse.

persons.name: Kenneth R. Feinberg
persons.role: Claims administration expert and Program Administrator
persons.context: Retained by the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein to design and administer the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.

persons.name: Camille S. Biros
persons.role: Claims administration expert and Program Administrator
persons.context: Retained by the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein to design and administer the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program alongside Kenneth R. Feinberg.

persons.name: Marci A. Hamilton
persons.context: A professor and victims' rights advocate who may be consulted by the Program Administrator to provide expertise on sexual abuse dynamics and victim sensitivities.

connections.description: Both are nationally recognized claims administration experts retained together to design and administer the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.
Feinberg was retained by the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein to administer the victim compensation program.
Biros was retained by the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein to administer the victim compensation program.
Hamilton may be consulted by the Administrator (Feinberg/Biros) to provide expert advice on sexual abuse cases and victim interactions.

events.title: Protocol Publication
events.description: The Epstein Victims' Compensation Program Protocol is issued, formally establishing the rules and procedures for victim claims.

keyFacts: The Epstein Victims' Compensation Program (EVCP) is a voluntary, independent program established to compensate victims of sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein, administered by Kenneth R. Feinberg and Camille S. Biros.
The program has no cap on aggregate or individual compensation amounts, and the Administrator has final, binding authority over eligibility and valuation decisions.
Eligibility extends to victims regardless of when or where the abuse occurred, the statute of limitations, or whether they previously settled with Epstein.
The protocol explicitly states that individuals who allegedly assisted Epstein in procuring other victims may be eligible if they acted under duress due to their own abuse by Epstein.
Claimants who accept compensation must sign a release but are not bound by confidentiality rules and are free to discuss their allegations with law enforcement or anyone else.
